Home video sales and rentals on DVD, Blu-ray, 4K Blu-ray, and of course, VHS and other retro formats, including the original RST Video stock;
An impeccable selection of video game consoles and games, also available for sale and rent;
Antique electronics, from VCR’s to turntables;

And much more.

We are planning to open the doors to a fresh, unique destination with the intention of keeping video store culture and physical media alive. This, my friends, is the pop-culture paradise we have dreamed of for 25 years.

What We Need & What You Get
·      While much of the store and stock have been untouched, there is a great deal of work to be done to renovate the store. We need to replace shelving, install a modern rental system, restore the signage, and promote the new RST Video!
·      In exchange for your support, we have a lot of merchandise and experiences available, including RST-branded clothing, invites to the grand opening, swag boxes, and more!
·      We have an agreement in place with the owners. RST Video WILL open. However, if we fail, any unused funds will be donated to Family Promise of Monmouth County Food and Shelter Services in Middletown, NJ.

Risks & Challenges
If you are not a fan of Kevin Smith or do not get the appeal of a video store in 2019, rest assured that this we plan to stand alone in practice, if not spirit.

We understand Smith’s fans.
We know how much we value the significance of RST video, as well as the looming shadow of video store nostalgia.
VHS is making a comeback! Even if you do not plan to buy or rent tapes, there will be plenty more to gravitate you.
We cannot do this without you! Tell us what you want to see at RST VIDEO!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can’t help financially, you can still help us spread the word about this campaign and about RST’s reopening! Every mention, post, tweet, and message helps us get one step closer! We appreciate any form of support!
 
Spread the word on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter, Snapchat, or whatever social media platform you use, and remember to use the tools on this campaign to share this Indiegogo!

story:
English version: https://thegiftofwiracochablog.wordpress.com

INTRODUZIONE

La ricerca di una terza via che coniughi arte e scienza è l'impulso che nel 2004 ha portato alla creazione di VID art|science. Grazie alla cura ed alla passione del Prof. Carlo Ventura (cardiologo e biologo molecolare esperto in medicina rigenerativa e vibrazionale) e di Julia von Stietencron (artista tessile e stilista) negli anni si è formato un gruppo di ricercatori ed artisti appartenenti a diversi ambiti e nazionalità. 

Nel novembre 2016 un evento decisivo: Cell Melodies, festival di 3 giorni svoltosi a Bologna, nel Teatro San Leonardo (in collaborazione con Angelica Festival) che ha avuto l'onore di ospitare vari artisti fra i quali Milford Graves, Alessandro Bergonzoni e Gianni Gebbia in esperimenti live diretti a colture viventi di cellule staminali informate dai ritmi, dalle parole e dai suoni prodotti sulla scena. La risposta di queste cellule dall'alto potere di metamorfosi, presenti in gran numero nei nostri corpi, è stata commovente: il loro profilo vibrazionale si è intensificato a tal punto da mostrare agli sguardi raccolti nel teatro gremito una danza di fotoni massimamente coerente.

Sono ormai molte le evidenze scientifiche che testimoniano della potenza rigenerativa insita nei suoni, nel gesto, nella forma e nei colori e che riconfigurano l'arte nella sua funzione rituale di cura e ri-connessione con le energie ed i cicli della Natura.

---

ABSTRACT

Su queste basi VID art|science ha concepito “Il dono de Wiracocha”, progetto di ricerca nell'ambito del Teatro Rituale. Tale formula designa un dispositivo culturale che attraverso l'atto performativo evoca ed incarna l'intensità delle antiche narrazioni mitiche e dei rituali ad esse connesse, armonizzandole con le meraviglie che le avanguardie della scienza tornano a dischiudere.

In questo viaggio di circa 45 giorni nelle magiche terre del Perù avremo come guide uomini e donne depositari di antiche tradizioni, condividendo la quotidianità e partecipando alle loro cerimonie. Ci ispireremo alla visione del mondo ed alle pratiche che costantemente rinnovano un fecondo ed equilibrato rapporto simbiotico con le forze della Natura. 

Questo percorso iniziatico fornirà il materiale per un film documentario che vede alla regia Stefano Croci, autore e co-fondatore di Caucaso Factory. Quest'opera tenterà di cogliere le fasi salienti del viaggio rielaborandole in una narrazione che affini e potenzi la volontà mitopoietica dell'intero progetto. 

Al ritorno, dopo una necessaria fase di re-integrazione e trasfigurazione dell'esperienza, VID art|science realizzerà uno spettacolo di Teatro Rituale a cura di Yuri Dini, il cui debutto è previsto nella seconda edizione di Cell Melodies (novembre 2017 - Teatro San Leonardo, Bologna).

In questa occasione, grazie all'equipe del Prof. Carlo Ventura, ci serviremo di una tecnica chiamata hyperspectral imaging, capace di cogliere il profilo vibrazionale delle cellule degli spettatori e dei performers. Questo ci permetterà di collezionare una serie di evidenze scientifiche dei mutamenti generati attraverso l'atto performativo. Queste saranno poi confrontate con i dati analogamente raccolti nelle cerimonie e nei rituali ai quali prenderemo parte durante il viaggio in Perù.

Il presente dialogo fra arte e scienza ci permetterà altresì di porre le basi per un'analisi comparata fra rito e teatro, nel tentativo di riconferire a quest'ultimo un ruolo decisivo nella crisi culturale che attraversa la nostra società.

Questo è il nostro contributo al movimento che da ogni angolo della Terra crea e lotta per un'età più bella. Un viaggio in Perù, alle radici della Cura, riportando nel “villaggio natio” un messaggio di speranza ed una serie di conoscenze e pratiche a disposizione di quanti vogliano unirsi a noi nel cammino. 

Vogliamo realizzare un film documentario del viaggio ed uno spettacolo che traduca e veicoli le antiche tecniche di cura che in quei luoghi vengono custodite e tramandate da millenni. 

Il 2 giugno partiremo, in ogni caso, ma solo con il tuo sostegno riusciremo a trasformare il viaggio in opera, a far sposare Arte e Cura e condividerne i frutti.

---

CRONOPROGRAMMA

・2 giugno 2017 - Volo Bologna-Lima

・3-5 giugno - Lima

Museo Nazionale di archeologia, antropologia e storia del Perù. Incontro con alcuni curanderos che nel tessuto urbano hanno sviluppato sistemi di cure sincretici, unendo saperi tradizionali a moderne discipline olistiche, in un costante dialogo con la medicina allopatica
Visita a mercati cittadini che offrono centinaia di rimedi naturali disponibili anche per la stragrande maggioranza della popolazione che non ha accesso alle cure “ufficiali”

・6-7 giugno - Ica, Nasca

Museo Cabrera. Luoghi di straordinari ritrovamenti archeologici che la cultura “ufficiale” non riesce ancora ad integrare nel corpus culturale che fornisce la base educativa delle scuole e delle università di tutto il mondo 

・8-14 giugno - Cuzco e dintorni 

Parteciperemo alla preparazione ed alle cerimonie in onore della Vergine di Qoyllur Rit'i, dichiarate patrimonio immateriale dell'umanità dall'Unesco. In questi giorni saremo ospiti dei Qero, antica etnia considerata la diretta discendente degli Inca e del loro preziosissimo patrimonio culturale

・15-23 giugno - Puerto Maldonado

・24 giugno - Inti Raymi

Cerimonia religiosa incaica in onore di Inti, il dio-sole. 
Segna il solstizio d'inverno nelle Ande dell'emisfero australe

・26 giugno - Lima

・28 giugno - Pucallpa

Ultimo avamposto urbano della selva amazzonica cui si può giungere via terra.Da qui, dopo gli approvvigionamenti necessari, un peke-peke (piccola imbarcazione in legno) ci traghetterà verso..

・29 giugno-10 luglio - Mayantuyacu

Centro di cura tradizionale Ashaninka: alcuni giorni nei quali, sotto la guida di Juan Flores, entreremo in contatto con alcune Piante Maestro, ed attraverso queste con la voce e le visioni della Terra. 

・11-14 luglio - Tingo Maria

Cueva de las lechuzas. Laguna de los milagros

・15 luglio - Lima, Marcahuasi

Cerimonia di ringraziamento alla terra ed alle persone che ci hanno accolti con spettacolo e laboratorio di teatro rituale gratuito, in collaborazione con Kinesfera Danza (Lima).

・18 luglio - Volo Lima-Bologna

・Novembre 2018 - Teatro San Leonardo, Bologna

Proiezione promo video documentario (Caucaso Factory). 
“Prima” dello spettacolo di Teatro Rituale a cura di Yuri Dini.

 

www.ildonodiwiracocha.com

story:
This project is a grassroots effort to celebrate the unique voices in our Queens, New York neighborhood. It is our statement to the world that we stand together, united, despite the power structures that attempt to separate us.

Meeting the Neighbors

Inside Norman Street began in 2015 at Outpost Artists Resources as a creative writing workshop for our neighbors on Norman Street. Local artist and community arts worker Libby Mislan lead weekly sessions with 12 residents who shared stories about their personal lives, which were turned into a beautiful book! At the performance for the project the residents read their stories as they were interpreted through live music and dance.  

Norman Street Today 

This year, Inside Norman Street returns! We will again  recruit 12 residents of Norman Street who will take part in six weeks of creative writing workshops, using movement, storytelling, and improv-based warm-ups. At the end of the workshops, the neighbors choose a story from their collections that they would like to co-direct as a multi-media piece using movement, music, and video to bring their story to life in collaboration with professional artists.

Our 2017 Neighbors 

Libby Mislan - Project Leader

Zoe Rappaport - Choreographer 

Yo-E Ryou - Graphic Designer 

Alex Nathanson - Video Artist 

Why Norman Street? 

Creating group art allows for bonds of trust to form amongst individuals across difference. The Inside Norman Street project in 2015 extended far beyond the final performance. The neighbors continued to connect in myriad ways, hosting one another for cooking classes, salsa lessons, dinners, and more. In this current political moment, we need to call upon creativity to reveal to us the beauty in our diversity.  

 

Where the money is going:

 

 

Respect: One Street at a Time 

New Yorkers can go years without knowing who their neighbors are, despite their living in such close proximity to each other. With our neighborhood rapidly gentrifying, longstanding community relationships are put in jeopardy. Mislan’s project forges friendship and empathy amongst new and long-term community residents to build back and maintain our block identity. 

We sincerely appreciate any support you can offer to this innovative approach to art-making!!

~The Team at Outpost

story:
“Every artist knows that he is engaged in an encounter with infinity, and that work done with heart and hand is ultimately expression of Life Itself.”

– Bernard Leach

 

HI THERE, I’M EMMA,

Some may know me as a photographer, others as a ceramicist but more importantly, creativity has been an integral part of my being for as long as I can remember. It is the fuel to my fire, the language that allows me to go beyond my self, explore liberally and fulfil my deepest curiosities.

Coupled with a hunger for authenticity, community and engagement, I have long found solace in collaboration with other creative minds and relish what comes to the surface when we explore new territory together from this place of intuitive connection. In a society where, if we’re honest, distractions from this sincere exploration are plentiful, I truly believe that the most promising way forward is as a collective.

A number of fateful twist and turns have led me to Bali, and I gotta say, it’s true what they tell ya – the gods really do work their magic here. Inspired by the abundance of rich creative tradition and nourished by the wholesome creative and spiritual lifestyle, I have found a space where I believe I may put these values into practice and serve to make a difference.

 

THE JOURNEY OF MAKASI

The term ‘makasi’ in Indonesian language comes from terima kasih. ‘Terima’ meaning to receive and ‘kasih’, to give. Together the two mean thank you.

The universal language of creativity unites the Makasi community and enables us to engage liberally with ourselves, our environment, our traditions, and within our diverse collective. This intimacy is passed onto our audience through our unique range of pieces that are designed with intention to accompany and bring presence to the quiet and abundant moments of our day to day.

It seems only appropriate to say Makasi and show gratitude for this enriching exchange of both giving and receiving.

Initially, working alongside a curated selection of traditional artisans in Indonesia, Makasi will provide a contemporary platform for them to tell their story and share their treasured traditions with an international audience. Collaboratively, we will design and curate a selection of intentionally made pieces intended to accompany everyday rituals with gratitude and simplicity. The Makasi blog and online store will feature this unique range - reaching, educating and growing a socially and ecologically conscious audience who choose to consume with transparency and intention.

Seeking to create new opportunities and progressive ideas amongst our community, collaboration will be encouraged between various mediums and generations, providing the platform for a diverse range of creative minds to engage and explore. Simplicity will be cherished throughout this process as we endeavour to provide a collection that offers a simple, timeless, functional aesthetic and allows the organic and intuitive allure of natural materials and the makers hand to be celebrated.

Our online content will strive to represent our artists in an authentic and engaging manner. Photographic documentation of the artists within their creative spaces alongside accompanying articles and regular topical blog posts will provide our audience with an intimate insight and allow them to be captivated by the creative process.

Rich in crafts, culture, tradition, beautiful natural materials and open to opportunities, Indonesia provides a fantastic platform for the initiation of the Makasi community. Following this establishment and with a reputable reputation behind us, our diversity will extend to cross-cultural collaboration as we unite East and West with an invitation to contemporary and traditional artists from New Zealand, Australia and throughout South East Asia to collaborate and join the collective. As the community extends and diversifies with representation from various cultural backgrounds, Makasi becomes a unifying centre and we are able to explore wholesome, progressive ideas amongst a supportive world-wide network, enriching the lives of artists and consumers worldwide.

Once the community has been established online and is self-sufficient, Makasi provides the platform to launch further projects and create more opportunities.

The physical home of the community will exist as a creative sanctuary. This space will house a gallery with rotating exhibitions and a retail area featuring the Makasi range. A collaborative work / event space will offer the opportunity for further community engagement. New Zealand or Indonesia will provide a home to the first Makasi hub, with the potential to expand worldwide.

Further initiatives could also include world-wide pop-up markets, workshops, creative exchanges, residencies or mentoring programs. As the community connects, the opportunities really are infinite. Collectively – our presence is stronger, as we strive to make the creative lifestyle forever more relevant in our contemporary society.

With much of the initial stages well underway including consideration of site design, branding, proposals and contracts, policies, payment procedures, artist recruitment and design philosophy, the platform for the Makasi community is already well established and the funding received will provide the support needed to launch this vision into reality. Alongside my own creative practice, my background in community work and as a gallery coordinator has provided me with a solid foundational skill set for the challenges that may arise as Makasi unfolds. I feel well equipped for this endeavor alongside a team of incredible artisans, designers, advisers and marketing experts. As we stand by these authentic intentions, keep the passion flame burning and remain open to organic evolution I am eager to watch this journey unfold.

 

TO MAKE IT HAPPEN

Reaching our campaign goal will provide the investment that is needed to establish the initial online platform for opportunity. These funds will be received with an immense amount of gratitude and will contribute to:

  • Generation of online blog, store and branding.

  • Cost of materials, sampling and production for the initial collection.

  • Production of eco friendly packaging and stationary.

  • Production of online video content.

 

TO SHOW OUR GRATITUDE

The first two people to donate $600 or more will receive a one-off anagama fired piece handmade by Emma Badeia. Accompanied by a hand-written letter, this will be carefully packaged and shipped to your destination.

Every donation of $100 or over will receive a personalised email and a digital copy of the very first Makasi publication produced for our initial exhibition in 2017. This beautifully designed book features insightful and intimate studio documentation of Bali-based artists accompanied by carefully crafted articles.

 

HOW YOU CAN HELP

If the vision of the Makasi community and its potential offerings is something that you feel you can get behind, then we would be hugely humbled and grateful for your support.

Donation of funds will be received graciously and contribute hugely to our online launch – every little bit really does count.

Share the love and spread the word to your friends, family and social media followings.

 

“Sediket demi sediket lama-lama menjadi bukit”

“Little by little, over time, we make a mountain”

Rich in crafts, culture, tradition, beautiful natural materials and open to opportunities, Indonesia provides a fantastic platform for the initiation of the Makasi community. Following this establishment and with a reputable reputation behind us, our diversity will extend to cross-cultural collaboration as we unite East and West with an invitation to contemporary and traditional artists from New Zealand, Australia and throughout South East Asia to collaborate and join the collective. As the community extends and diversifies with representation from various cultural backgrounds, Makasi becomes a unifying centre and we are able to explore wholesome, progressive ideas amongst a supportive world-wide network, enriching the lives of artists and consumers worldwide.
Once the community has been established online and is self-sufficient, Makasi provides the platform to launch further projects and create more opportunities.
The physical home of the community will exist as a creative sanctuary. This space will house a gallery with rotating exhibitions and a retail area featuring the Makasi range. A collaborative work / event space will offer the opportunity for further community engagement. New Zealand or Indonesia will provide a home to the first Makasi hub, with the potential to expand worldwide.
Further initiatives could also include world-wide pop-up markets, workshops, creative exchanges, residencies or mentoring programs. As the community connects, the opportunities really are infinite. Collectively – our presence is stronger, as we strive to make the creative lifestyle forever more relevant in our contemporary society.
With much of the initial stages well underway including consideration of site design, branding, proposals and contracts, policies, payment procedures, artist recruitment and design philosophy, the platform for the Makasi community is already well established and the funding received will provide the support needed to launch this vision into reality. Alongside my own creative practice, my background in community work and as a gallery coordinator has provided me with a solid foundational skill set for the challenges that may arise as Makasi unfolds. I feel well equipped for this endeavor alongside a team of incredible artisans, designers, advisers and marketing experts. As we stand by these authentic intentions, keep the passion flame burning and remain open to organic evolution I am eager to watch this journey unfold.
 
TO MAKE IT HAPPEN
Reaching our campaign goal will provide the investment that is needed to establish the initial online platform for opportunity. These funds will be received with an immense amount of gratitude and will contribute to:

Generation of online blog, store and branding.
Cost of materials, sampling and production for the initial collection.
Production of eco friendly packaging and stationary.
Production of online video content.

 
TO SHOW OUR GRATITUDE
The first two people to donate $600 or more will receive a one-off anagama fired piece handmade by Emma Badeia. Accompanied by a hand-written letter, this will be carefully packaged and shipped to your destination.
Every donation of $100 or over will receive a personalised email and a digital copy of the very first Makasi publication produced for our initial exhibition in 2017. This beautifully designed book features insightful and intimate studio documentation of Bali-based artists accompanied by carefully crafted articles.
 
HOW YOU CAN HELP
If the vision of the Makasi community and its potential offerings is something that you feel you can get behind, then we would be hugely humbled and grateful for your support.
Donation of funds will be received graciously and contribute hugely to our online launch – every little bit really does count.
Share the love and spread the word to your friends, family and social media followings.
 
“Sediket demi sediket lama-lama menjadi bukit”
“Little by little, over time, we make a mountain”

story:
I have been fortunate enough to receive a very good education and have been exposed to the arts from a very young age. I consider myself even luckier to have grown up in a family that always reminded me to inspire and encourage people who did not have the same opportunities that I did.

I am trying to create an open space for the local artistic community, where composers and writers can create in a peaceful and warm environment, where composers can get their music performed without having to book an expensive venue, where performers can meet and collaborate with composers, and where artists from other disciplines will also be able to expose their art for free! That will create an atmosphere for discussion that will inspire artistic progress and development, and that strong bonds will be established between artists from various disciplines!  

I am hoping that this will be an inviting space will not only serve local artists but will slowly introduce contemporary art to the lives of the youth of our local community, inspiring them to believe in themselves, embrace their individuality, express themselves, and find their voice.

story:
EXPECTED OPENING APRIL 2018

Hello to everybody. We would like to offer you the opportunity to join us and to be a part of our team in order to create this Museum & Experience together. Jump with us in the past, to the fantastic world of Giacomo Casanova - and create the future.

“Giacomo Casanova Museum & Experience” will be the first Museum dedicated to the poet, musician, adventurer, lover, Giacomo Casanova and will be located in Venice - the place where Casanova left his spirit. We’ve decided to call it “Museum & Experience” because it won't be just a dusty museum, where you will be able to discover paintings, memorabilia and more, but it will be a unique experience with high technologies,  multimedia, which will let you revive the romantic adventures of Giacomo Casanova, feeling the sensation of the life of this eclectic man.

Giacomo Casanova has loved and has been loved like no other man in history. That's why we have created a special experience to deliver the "loved letters" and make you feel interactive while visiting the museum. 

Enjoy the video and discover the project behind the scene.

  • PROMOTIONAL VIDEO:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K8_5NYPqNcQ

  • DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT:

Carlo Parodi, the founder of Giacomo Casanova Limited and Giacomo Casanova Foundation, had the vision to create something never built before - an entire Museum with a real multimedia experience dedicated to one of the most important characters of our history - Giacomo Casanova. “I’ve decided to offer a tribute to Casanova, a man of love, poetry, music, and adventure”. 

Furthermore, this concept will help the local businesses to develop tourism and increase work opportunities in Venice.  The Mayor of Venice was incredibly excited about this project and he is currently working towards its complete realization with us.

However, this project needs to be supported in order to come into effect, hence, we have already made some prior calculations based on the statistical data with regards to the tourism in Venice:

  • *AFFLUENCE - our prevision :

First year: 80,000 / 130,000 visitors

Second year: 130,000 / 220,000

Third year: up to 300,000

TOTAL VISITORS IN VENICE EVERY YEAR: 15,000,000 / 20,000,000  

*Details discussed with the Venice Cultural Committee in cooperation with an important transport company of the Lagoon.

  • CASANOVA MUSEUM & EXPERIENCE AROUND THE WORLD:

We would like to take this experience all around the world and not only restrict it to Venice. Our aim is to reach the numerous masses across the globe, to create a new museum, both permanent and temporary.

Below is the list:

1) VENICE - PERMANENT MUSEUM

2) PRAGUE - NEXT PERMANENT MUSEUM

3) SAINT PETERSBURG - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

4) LONDON - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

5 PARIS - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

6) NEW YORK - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

7) TOKYO - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

8) BEIJING - TEMPORARY MUSEUM

  • HOW WE WILL INVEST THE FUNDS COLLECTED: 

  • WHY EXTRA FUNDS:

The amount the project will reach will be invested in the permanent Museum in Venice. We do expect extra funding in order to plan the next permanent Museum that will be in Prague.

  • 1700’s IN VENICE:

We will discover with the Museum & Experience not only the life of Giacomo Casanova but also the customs and traditions of the magic period of the18th century. Once Venice was a leading European economic and trading power. 

JOIN US ON THIS IMPORTANT PROJECT & ENJOY IT ALONG WITH US!!!

 

Thank you,

Kind regards,

CARLO PARODI

PRESIDENT – GIACOMO CASANOVA FOUNDATION

FOLLOW US ON :

FACEBOOK: https://www.facebook.com/giacomocasanovafoundat...

INSTAGRAM: https://www.instagram.com/giacomocasanovafounda...

YOUTUBE: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCGsFA0hg6ncjFq...

VIMEO: https://vimeo.com/home/myvideos

*Kindly note the pictures are for reference purpose only and the final design may vary*

story:
Immerge (v): to plunge into or immerse oneself in something.

In a world that often feels harsh and unforgiving with minds the same, Immerge is a space that invites us to feel safe and nurtured, to celebrate, and to reawaken to the beauty of the small things. Because when we nurture ourselves, we can walk in the world knowing that we are an essential part of it all.

What is Immerge?

An immersive art exhibit
A performance space
A dance party
A healing for ourselves & our planet
A journey
A collaborative grassroots movement
A space for Orlando creatives to showcase their talents
A passion project

Who is Involved?

Immerge is curated and organized by Summer Thyme Designs (that's me below!). I am a multimedia artist and healer based in Orlando, FL. I've always been interested in exploring a variety of creative endeavors - painting, drawing, event organizing, reiki, sewing, dancing, interior design. I used to get frustrated at myself for not being able to choose just one thing - until I realized that having immersed myself in so many different mediums presents a unique opportunity to blend them into what has become my current passion project: Immerge.

I deeply enjoy the process of co-creation and am excited to bring to life this vision of community healing through artistic expression. 

Performances and art by:  Daniel Koenigkann, NUYA, AHHA Dance, PMFL Productions, Light Flora, Summer Thyme, & many more.

Venue provided by Living Vitalitea Kombucha

Birth of the Project

Immerge began as a longing for a space that felt both nurturing and expansive, a space layered with art and garnished with a sense of belonging. This longing was the seed that is now beginning to sprout. 

This seed has been germinating in a bed of exploration. For the past several years I've been immersing myself in the arts; exploring the process of creation both within myself and within the community. It began with a love of painting and a recognition of the healing power of art. Soon I integrated into my repertoire theater, dance, illustration, sculpting, reiki, furniture design, and music. At the core of why I create is a sense of aliveness that breeds transformation and I want to share that with others. 

With creativity at the core and a lot of experience managing teams throughout high school, college, and work, I feel adequately prepared and excited to gather all of my experience and passion into one space. 

What Will Happen There?

The Living Vitalitea Brewery will be transformed for three days into a completely immersive art experience. Guests will be guided through a creative journey from the outside world into the nurturing womb of creation. There will be curated live musical performances, dance performances, a dance party, and a gallery space that will all be blended together into one cohesive experience. 

Immerge is a roughly three hour event, taking place April 16,17, and 18. Tickets are limited to just 30 people per night and guests will be asked to arrive on time an stay through the duration of the event to create an opportunity for intimacy and intention.

Why It Matters

It's been a wild year for many of us.  With so much outside of our control it can be difficult to feel like we have any place here. Immerge challenges that assumption by creating a space that allows us to connect to one another, to ourselves, and to our divinity. It is both an art space and a healing space that with your support we can bring to life. 

How Your Contribution Will Help

This is a grassroots event and we're going to need a lot of support from our community to pull it off. We already have the commitments of local artists and businesses. Now we just need the funds to help us with creating installations, compensating the performers, creating merch, and ideally a little bit extra to help us save for our next event. 

Our total fundraising goal is $4200. Ticket sales will account for about $2500 of this goal, leaving us with $1700 left to raise. Our IndieGogo goal is $1900 to account for their cut and processing fees. 

This money will first be allocated to materials needed for installations. These will play a big part in creating the atmosphere for the event and will create little wonderlands for guests to explore. We plan to use primarily found, donated, and recycled materials, keeping our costs pretty low and exhibiting a little kindness to Mother Earth in the process. Mostly this will be for things like paint and used fabrics. 

The remaining funds will be divided proportionally between performers. Any extra amount raised over the goal will go into a fund for future projects and events!

Please note that tickets to Immerge will not be sold through IndieGogo. If you plan to attend our event (and we hope that you do!) tickets will not be included in your donation. Keep an eye out for ticket sales launching in February, and in the meantime sign up for some our perks donated by our awesome collaborators!

The Perks

Gratitude - $1 or more

Sticker - $5 or more

Summer Thyme Designs printed postcard with handwritten note + previous perks- $10 or more

T-Shirt + previous perks - $50 or more

Exclusive Offers: These perks are available to just one or two contributors so be sure to act fast!

Living Vitalitea Kombucha (mixed flavors) - $20 for six pack $36 for twelve pack

Photography by Rho 1 Hour Photoshoot + 14 edited photos -  $30 or more

\

1 Hour Reiki Session with Summer Thyme (In Person or Distance) - $60 or more

3.5lb box of Fungi Jon's Local Mushrooms - $60 or more

Light Flora 8" x 6" Nature Inspired Framed Artwork - $75 or more

Summer Thyme Designs One of a Kind Tapestry  - "Sky in Bloom" - $80 or more

One Hour Branding Consultation with Yuan Chang - $100 or more

Summer Thyme Designs Original Painting - "Infinite Joy" - $280 or more

Art as a Tool for Manifestation and Healing Six Week Online Course - $300 or more

Summer Thyme Designs Original Painting - "Back to Earth" - $380 or more

Summer Thyme Designs Original Painting - "Sky in Bloom" - $380 or more

If you cannot support this project financially you can still help us out by sharing this page or donating supplies! Below is our wishlist:

Fabric (A LOT of it) - Primarily neutral shades, pinks, reds, and greens
Yarn - neutrals, pinks, reds, greens
Star/Galaxy projector
Spray Paint - primarily neutral shades and greens
Thick wire - for installations
Fresh Flowers & other live plants

Thank you so much to everyone who has shown us support. It is through the support of this community that any of this is possible and I am eternally grateful.

story:
According to our history, we're all descendants of immigrants to Canada except for our aboriginal cousins.  A lot of us grew up learning our family history through the passing down of "griot" history, heritage and genealogy.  

That history made you and your ancestry strong to prosper in a new land. Our  communities intertwined to progress our country.  Our offspring, knowledgeable about their legacy, learned little of their "Canadian" history.  Some of us learned little of our culture through fear of antagonism, familial secrecy, indoctrination of "political" history, and lack of education.

We now have an opportunity to tell our story through the integration of "true" Black Canadian history into the educational system and increase awareness through leadership, educators, families and friends, towards appreciating the values of inclusivity, collaboration and knowledge of our "Community, Roots & Cultures".

The 2017 venue includes:

A HBHAS Freedom Festival Speakers' Forum on August 4th, at the Royal Botanical Gardens, Burlington, which includes historical, genealogical, and cultural speakers, music and spoken word plus a marketplace of historical book suppliers and community/cultural vendors. 

On Saturday August 5 there will be a HBHAS Halton Freedom Festival Celebration at Spencer Smith Park, inclusive of exquisite musical and dance acts, youth and children's events, artistic/musical and historical forums, and an extensive marketplace of cultural cuisine, community and cultural association partners and, genealogists and historians/authors and cultural contributors. 

We will also be presenting a HBHAS Canadian Black Art Exhibit to take place at Halton Hills Cultural Centre in Georgetown, Ontario from August 21 to September 2nd incorporating Artists'  and Speaker presentations. 

All venues are open and promoted to the public.  We know this festival can grow to the size of the Burlington Ribfest and Sound of Music events and enhance and augment Halton's community and cultural prestige and status.  We are also collaborating with a number of community partners in presentations and workshops within schools and community centers throughout the year.

Towards this journey, we are seeking $20,000 by June 1st, 2017, to support our inaugural multicultural Halton Freedom Festival.  Having been incorporated in affiliation with the Ontario Historical Society in August 2016, the HBHAS is not eligible for the 1 year incorporation status required to obtain grants for 2017 even though the organization has been in existence since 2005 as a committee.  It is for this reason that we are requesting a partnership with interested individuals, companies and associations towards financially supporting the Halton Freedom Festival.  We would also like to offer free admission to our Halton Freedom Festival as almost all festivals at Spencer Smith Park are free and open to the public. Your support is appreciated and will be identified, with your permission, throughout our marketing and venue programs. 

Halton Population Statistics

  • In Halton-Peel, there is significantly faster population growth among immigrant and visible minority communities compared to the overall population.
  • Between 2001 and 2006, the region’s visible minority population increased by 76%. This was about four and half times faster than the 17% growth rate of the total population. In fact, the growth rates of the visible minority population in each of the area municipalities surpass those of the total population.
  • The Town of Milton, the fastest-growing community in Canada, experienced a 780% increase of its visible minority population. It is now home to over 9,000 individuals of that population sub-group.
  • The visible minority population is also younger. For example, over one-quarter (26%) of the population is under the age of 15 as compared to 21% for the non visible minority population.
  • The 2012/13 Halton Youth Survey reported that elevated psychological distress is reported by 34% of students. This percentage represents about 341,000 Ontario students.

Every survey is communicating to us that the only direction to take towards a progressive, passionate, prosperous future is through equality, justice, inclusivity, and diversity/cultural/historical education.  The Halton Black History Awareness Committee is focused on promoting self awareness and knowledge through implementation of cultural forums within the educational systems, promoting cultural history through speaker presentations, cultural events culminating in a 2017 Emancipation "Freedom" Festival, art/music/literary presentations, and educational/historical and genealogical forums, independently and in collaboration with community partners.

We have seen the significant benefits in cultural education including:

  • Self awareness, knowledge and confidence/self esteem building
  • Community and cultural collaboration and education
  • Prosperity evolving from diversity collaboration and appreciation
  • Enhancement of our cultural and heritage community and its progressive evolution
  • Economic influx from tourism increase, cultural cuisine, theatre and art, and
  • A decline of prejudice, criminality, bullying, and injustices

An increasing number of individuals in our communities are appreciating true, and often hidden, Canadian history.  Through appreciating that our Emancipation was progressed by multi cultures and that we, individually, are often derivatives of multi cultures; have experienced similar prejudices and enslavement within our own cultures; desire the best that life can offer; and will gain in personal development when self knowledge is learned, we realize, as many proponents of inclusivity and acceptance state, that cultural education is a mandate that will alleviate our prejudices and promote progression.

With the growth of visible minorities in Canada, mixed marriages and relationships, cultural and faith integration, and gender equality, our programs and events will definitely enhance one's inquisitiveness, search for self esteem and confidence, and community progress.

Knowing one's history and culture is knowing one's self.  This knowledge will give you strength, focus, inspiration, ambition and progress.  The earlier we can learn about ourselves, our heritage, our culture and our people, and that of others, the more we will appreciate how the home, community and individual can best progress.  

Our HBHAS team is a passionate group of multi-culturals, dedicated towards implementing cultural education into the public and institutional mindset towards appreciating the values of inclusivity, equality, and self development while depleting bullying, prejudice and inequality on any and all levels. 

We are a group of educators, life coaches, community business leaders, graphics/social media and technical specialists, event planners, youth representatives, and community contributors with a passion and focus in augmenting the Regional communities' cultural appreciation.

HBHAS invites you to take the journey with us!  See what a difference a little history can make in the preservation of passing on our heritage, culture and stories to the next generation.

We welcome all  corporate and personal contributors, committee membership, volunteer participation, musicians/artists/ historians/ authors and, community and educational representatives to join in. 

Thank you for your interest and consideration.

Dennis Scott, Chair

Halton Black History Awareness Society (HBHAS)

We now have an opportunity to tell our story through the integration of "true" Black Canadian history into the educational system and increase awareness through leadership, educators, families and friends, towards appreciating the values of inclusivity, collaboration and knowledge of our "Community, Roots & Cultures".
The 2017 venue includes:
A HBHAS Freedom Festival Speakers' Forum on August 4th, at the Royal Botanical Gardens, Burlington, which includes historical, genealogical, and cultural speakers, music and spoken word plus a marketplace of historical book suppliers and community/cultural vendors. 
On Saturday August 5 there will be a HBHAS Halton Freedom Festival Celebration at Spencer Smith Park, inclusive of exquisite musical and dance acts, youth and children's events, artistic/musical and historical forums, and an extensive marketplace of cultural cuisine, community and cultural association partners and, genealogists and historians/authors and cultural contributors. 
We will also be presenting a HBHAS Canadian Black Art Exhibit to take place at Halton Hills Cultural Centre in Georgetown, Ontario from August 21 to September 2nd incorporating Artists'  and Speaker presentations. 
All venues are open and promoted to the public.  We know this festival can grow to the size of the Burlington Ribfest and Sound of Music events and enhance and augment Halton's community and cultural prestige and status.  We are also collaborating with a number of community partners in presentations and workshops within schools and community centers throughout the year.
Towards this journey, we are seeking $20,000 by June 1st, 2017, to support our inaugural multicultural Halton Freedom Festival.  Having been incorporated in affiliation with the Ontario Historical Society in August 2016, the HBHAS is not eligible for the 1 year incorporation status required to obtain grants for 2017 even though the organization has been in existence since 2005 as a committee.  It is for this reason that we are requesting a partnership with interested individuals, companies and associations towards financially supporting the Halton Freedom Festival.  We would also like to offer free admission to our Halton Freedom Festival as almost all festivals at Spencer Smith Park are free and open to the public. Your support is appreciated and will be identified, with your permission, throughout our marketing and venue programs. 
Halton Population Statistics

In Halton-Peel, there is significantly faster population growth among immigrant and visible minority communities compared to the overall population.
Between 2001 and 2006, the region’s visible minority population increased by 76%. This was about four and half times faster than the 17% growth rate of the total population. In fact, the growth rates of the visible minority population in each of the area municipalities surpass those of the total population.
The Town of Milton, the fastest-growing community in Canada, experienced a 780% increase of its visible minority population. It is now home to over 9,000 individuals of that population sub-group.
The visible minority population is also younger. For example, over one-quarter (26%) of the population is under the age of 15 as compared to 21% for the non visible minority population.
The 2012/13 Halton Youth Survey reported that elevated psychological distress is reported by 34% of students. This percentage represents about 341,000 Ontario students.

Every survey is communicating to us that the only direction to take towards a progressive, passionate, prosperous future is through equality, justice, inclusivity, and diversity/cultural/historical education.  The Halton Black History Awareness Committee is focused on promoting self awareness and knowledge through implementation of cultural forums within the educational systems, promoting cultural history through speaker presentations, cultural events culminating in a 2017 Emancipation "Freedom" Festival, art/music/literary presentations, and educational/historical and genealogical forums, independently and in collaboration with community partners.
We have seen the significant benefits in cultural education including:

Self awareness, knowledge and confidence/self esteem building
Community and cultural collaboration and education
Prosperity evolving from diversity collaboration and appreciation
Enhancement of our cultural and heritage community and its progressive evolution
Economic influx from tourism increase, cultural cuisine, theatre and art, and
A decline of prejudice, criminality, bullying, and injustices

An increasing number of individuals in our communities are appreciating true, and often hidden, Canadian history.  Through appreciating that our Emancipation was progressed by multi cultures and that we, individually, are often derivatives of multi cultures; have experienced similar prejudices and enslavement within our own cultures; desire the best that life can offer; and will gain in personal development when self knowledge is learned, we realize, as many proponents of inclusivity and acceptance state, that cultural education is a mandate that will alleviate our prejudices and promote progression.
With the growth of visible minorities in Canada, mixed marriages and relationships, cultural and faith integration, and gender equality, our programs and events will definitely enhance one's inquisitiveness, search for self esteem and confidence, and community progress.
Knowing one's history and culture is knowing one's self.  This knowledge will give you strength, focus, inspiration, ambition and progress.  The earlier we can learn about ourselves, our heritage, our culture and our people, and that of others, the more we will appreciate how the home, community and individual can best progress.  
Our HBHAS team is a passionate group of multi-culturals, dedicated towards implementing cultural education into the public and institutional mindset towards appreciating the values of inclusivity, equality, and self development while depleting bullying, prejudice and inequality on any and all levels. 
We are a group of educators, life coaches, community business leaders, graphics/social media and technical specialists, event planners, youth representatives, and community contributors with a passion and focus in augmenting the Regional communities' cultural appreciation.
HBHAS invites you to take the journey with us!  See what a difference a little history can make in the preservation of passing on our heritage, culture and stories to the next generation.
We welcome all  corporate and personal contributors, committee membership, volunteer participation, musicians/artists/ historians/ authors and, community and educational representatives to join in. 
Thank you for your interest and consideration.
Dennis Scott, Chair
Halton Black History Awareness Society (HBHAS)

story:
My name is Derek Lapierre - aka "Oldschool".  I am the Chairman of the Hamilton Skateboard Assembly (HSA), and the founder / organizer of the annual skateboard contest at Beasley Park.

Currently the biggest obstacle preventing the Hamilton Skateboard Assembly from organizing skateboard events in our city is the cost of insurance. Last year the HSA paid over $800 in insurance & city permit fees for a one day event at Beasley skatepark. We want to have a 2 day event this year to celebrate the 25th annual, but we need your assistance.

2017 is a big milestone for us. Not only are we celebrating the 25th annual Beasley Sk8 Jam, it is also the HSA's 15th anniversary. In 2002 (the same year as our 10th annual "Beaz Comp") we officially formed the Hamilton Skateboard Assembly

We want to make the 25th Hamilton Sk8 Jam at Beasley something extra special this year, but we need your financial help to do it.

PLEASE DONATE!

We have a ton of photo albums of past HSA activities, and info about upcoming events on our Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/HamiltonSkateboardAsse...

To learn more about Hamilton skateboard culture at Beasley, the history of the HSA, and view some footage from the 1st Beasley skateboard contest, check out this short documentary:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pRzI4KOtjo4

story:
With a heart to help people along with innovative ideas Maurice Savage Jr. (Together We Good) takes on the job of giving back to others. Beliving its better to give than recieve Maurice gives in a way where indivuals are unaware of who the giver is. 

Hidden cameras capture priceless emotions of surprise and disbelief. From tears to cheers, lifes most beautiful expressions knocks on the heart of Americans. By building this founding of love it would completly shake the United States as we know it today. 

As the show is introduced, it will not only have a positive affect in our neighborhoods and communities but it challenges the viewer to become what they see.   

The amount of funding we're looking for is $10,000, which can be used quickly and utilized where there is need. Distribution plans for the money will provide books for college students, paying rent and utillities, purchases of school clothes and supplies for children whose parents cannot, purchasing groceries, paying medical bills or prescreptions and meals for homeless.

story:
My name is Mkrtich Tonoyan, and I am an interdisciplinary artist and cultural manager based in Yerevan, Armenia. I am the founder and, since 2006, have been the co-director of ACOSS - the Armenian Art Centre of Social Studies – an international artist in residence. We are a member of Res Artis Worldwide network of artist residencies and the Microresidence International Network. I have been active in the professional field of contemporary art since graduating from the Academy of Fine Arts in Yerevan in 2002, and I regularly present creative projects and lectures on Armenian culture around the world. In 2010, I was awarded a mobility grant from the Euro Cultural Foundation to research models of artist residencies in the UK. In 2011, I was granted professional development funding from the Open Society Foundation to research artist residencies' management practice in the USA.

I am married, and we have four daughters.

Our Campaign Team
We are the ACOSS team, a group of Armenian and international artists committed to supporting and developing contemporary art in Armenia. 

ACOSS Artist in Residence program

The aim of ACOSS is to support the development of contemporary creativity and to assist local Armenian and international artists and scholars to organize exhibitions, conferences, research projects, seminars, and workshops concerning local art and current political and social situations. Our artist-in-residence program is a platform/meeting point where local and international artists and art professionals connect, develop links, and initiate cross border cultural exchange projects.

Since 2006, ACOSS AIR has welcomed over 200 international artists and guests from 40 countries. The ACOSS artist residency program is a long term social practice for me, a piece of my art, where my friends, the community where I am based, and my family are all involved. We meet at an intersection of Armenian hospitality and contemporary art. Here, we regularly collaborate with organizations, internationally to provide cultural exchange opportunities, and locally to develop socially engaged projects supporting social change, particularly in the peripheries and war affected zones of Armenia.


Our socially-engaged practice

As co-director of ACOSS I have initiated and coordinated many social and community development projects in Yerevan, Gyumri, Chambarak, on the Armenian borders, and other places. Projects include: Supporting Integration of Invalids into Society (2012 - 2017), Supporting Education on Border Zones and Supporting Social Integration of Syrian Refugees into New Resettlement Territories. During implementation of such projects we collaborate with many local and international organizations, and several of our visiting artists opt to get involved.

Our plan to grow

After 11 amazing years, we are now ready to take the next step in the development of the ACOSS artist residency program. Our current studio is a small space, 38 m/sq, and we want to grow! Finally, after years of trying, last year we were able to purchase a piece of land next to the studio and receive permission from the Yerevan city council to start renovation and expansion of our live/work studios to 200 m/sq - nearly five times more space. Having received permission and approval for our building plan, we've put together a dedicated project team and raised enough money to get the project underway. We started construction last year and built the shell of the new building. However, all funds have been exhausted. With Stage 1 successfully completed, we are now fundraising for Stage 2 to finish all the building work for the permit deadline of May 2018.

Since our organization's commencement, we have developed a close international network that has enable ACOSS to thrive in an isolated country. To continue growing, we need your support.

What we want to achieve

This is a big project and in my country there is no literarily way to get funding or any kind of sponsorship. We are looking to our international communities to support this initiative and help us reach our goals. Armenia is an isolated, mono ethnic country with a lack of funding support for the arts. We believe Armenia needs a truly international art center to welcome guest to our wonderful country.

By increasing the space for our art center we will be able to achieve so much more:

  • Host up to 6-8 visitors at the same time, creating a real international and interdisciplinary atmosphere for creativity;
  • Establish an exchange studio, in the ‘microresidency’ model, available for studio exchange programs with other countries;
  • Host YOU as a contributor who would like to join our network, visit our art space and experience Armenian culture;
  • One of the rooms will be open also as a rental space for visitors; friends or relative of our visiting artist, or for those who wish to get to know Armenian culture alongside artists in a creative space;
  • The creativity we encourage doesn’t have boarders. We host artists from around the world to undertake research, production and exhibitions in Armenia;
  • Develop an educational dimension of ACOSS introducing socially engaged practices as a form of art to our emerging Armenian artists;
  • Continue to develop our ethos and mission as an international art center based in the community, with strong social impact towards social change;
  • Develop a self-funding model to keep our independent art institution thriving.


What We Need

We need support from the international community to reach our goals.

Our building total costs including official permits, municipal inspections, materials and labour are $89,500. Over the last 2 years we have raised $42,000 in cash donations towards land purchase and permits, and the building materials required to construct the building shell. All our work thus far has been undertaken with volunteer labour from our neighbours and friends. We are proud to say, the support we have already received has enable us to complete stage 1 of the project.

We now need to raise a further $47,500 for the materials to complete stage 2 - to finish the project by May 2018, the deadline for official inspection.

Cost breakdown:

$ 4,800 - 4000 stones and bricks                           - (price for 1 brick - $ 10)
$ 700   - 20 m³ sand                                                         - (price for 1 m³ - $ 35)
$ 1,500 - 30 m² tiles                                                         - (price for 1 m² - $ 55)
$ 800 - 8 taps and plumbing system                      - (price for 1 tap - $ 100)
$ 2,300 - 23 m³ concrete                          - (price for 1 m³ concrete - $ 100)
$ 1,500 - 10 ton cement                               - (price for 1 ton cement - $ 150)
$ 2000 - 80 m² wooden floor                  - (price for 10 m² parquet - $ 250)
$ 1,800 - 6 m³ wood for construction          - (price for 1 m³ wood - $ 300)
$ 4,440 - 12 windows                                            - (price for 1 window - $ 370)
$ 3,260 - 6 doors                                                        - (price for 1 door  - $ 540)
$ 700 - Wire (Electricity system)                - (price for total wiring  - $ 700)
$ 1,000 - Equipment (El. system)                - (price for El. system - $ 1000)
​$ 1,200 - Plaster, paints, glue for tiles, varnish
$ 2000 - Staircase
$ 3000 - Heating system
$ 4000 - Roof with waterproofing and thermal insulation

$ 4,275 - Campaign fee 9 %
$ 4,335 - Perks international shipping 10 %
$ 3,890 - Contributor Perks 10 %

Total - $47,500

As much as possible, we are using eco-materials, working to European standards, and encouraging creativity in our processes.

What if we don’t reach our goal, or raise even more?!

If we don’t reach entire goal of fundraising, we will spend the money raised on the primary construction needs such as concrete or stones, roof insulation, windows etc, and continue with our fundraising.

But if we raise more than our goal we will put funds into the next stage of renovations for furniture (beds, chairs, easels, shells for library, tables, kitchen furniture), facilities for a small gallery, a library, and to support artists production process and presentation (projectors, cables, computers, printers, point lights, etc.) and other such essentials. 


Our window to the world

We are developing an international art space and our door is always open. ACOSS already appears on the map of the contemporary art landscape, proof that with motivation but limited sources you still can do valuable and noticeable things with great impact. Contributors who join our campaign will also join our network where they can keep supporting creativity and have a space to stay and enjoy art in Armenia any time they visit.



Perks of Donating...

You could recieve one of our beautiful perks including artworks by Armenian and former resident artists. Perks became a sort of fun part of our campaign. When our neighbors learnt about this perks system and how it is going to work, we keep receiving many, many different things from them to offer to our contributors.


You will receive CD or DVD of Armenian traditional and folk music and dance, performed by famous contemporary musician Norayr Kartashyan and Van Project, Andranik Manukyan and Gata band.

Get a Gift! Perks from the community. 

 

Get Prints! Original artistic prints by local and international artists.

Get an Original Artwork! Original art works (ceramic, oil, bronze) by local and international artists.

We will contact you sending full list of available perks to learn about your preference.

As a friend of ACOSS, we invite you to stay with us, as an artist in residence, or as our guest, or the opportunity to award a residency to an artist of your choice.
As a contributor to this campaign, and in the spirit of Armenian friendship, we offer you the opportunity to be an honorary ‘shareholder’ in our project and a lifetime friend for our art center.

And if you visit us in Armenia, we will be guide you to enjoy ancient monuments, share a traditional dinner with an Armenian family, participate in Armenian cultural events, and of course, raise a glass of our famous Armenian brandy.

Successful track record with projects like this.

Main example is the original studio that we are expanding now. I started building it in 2002 with help of friends, our family and community. Permission giving us to build was temporarily and we didn’t own the land and it was going to be temporarily. It took us 3 years to finish the construction. After finishing main construction work we have been developing it since 2005, each year adding something new on the building interior making it more comfortable for our visiting guests and suitable for small events doing there.


2 years ago, when we came to agreement with our government to get the studio permanently, not to use temporarily, to be able to invest there and develop as an professional art space, city municipality before giving us that certificate send to us building inspection group to check the quality of the building. We past the inspection and got the certificate of ownership and permission to use it for public events as well. That means, what we building work we did was in acceptable quality. That’s why that gave us permission to start expanding project and also permit to do main works on the construction by ourselves.

Risks & Challenges

If during building we change the project or design or don’t follow the project plan approved by Yerevan municipality, we run the risk of a big penalty. So we stick closely to the plan! Our permit for building expires by a strict deadline of May 2018, we have to complete the building and pass all inspections by that date.

To have the project complete by the deadline we need find necessary budget to finish the construction.  We just will keep trying more campaigns until we get necessary budget and complete the 2nd stage of the project.

How else can you help us? 

Join us in our mission to develop an international cultural exchange space and art center for our local community. Help us with promotion our campaign and follow our progress…

If you have any additional questions, don’t hesitate to contact us at: office@acoss.org


Join to our network and support campaign!
ACOSS team

Mattie Midgette's Store and House were placed                                                   on the National Register of Historic Places in 2004

 

Outer Banks Beachcomber Museum

Hello, my name is Dorothy Hope, I live in Nags Head North Carolina with my partner                       Chaz Winkler, and we own and steward historic Mattie Midgette's Store and the astounding         collection of seaside relics her daughter, Nellie Myrtle Pridgen, amassed over a lifetime                  of beachcombing that is housed within. For the past 15 years we have opened Mattie’s Store intermittently, allowing thousands of visitors to view Nellie’s beachcombing collection, the    best of which she had gradually spread over the shelves of her mother’s once thriving grocery.

During that time the collection has become legendary. In 2015, internationally recognized author and sea glass expert Richard LaMotte wrote about the importance of Nell’s collection     to the beachcombing community in his second book, “The Lure of Sea Glass”:

"In old Nags Head, on the Outer Banks of North Carolina, is an important piece of history that could soon be lost to the fury of an Atlantic hurricane. Inside a weary 1920s bungalow patiently sits the most extraordinary and diverse collection of seaside relics ever amassed by a beachcomber. Known today as the Outer Banks Beachcomber Museum, this classic coastal cottage was once a local Nags Head grocery store and home to Nellie Myrtle Pridgen."

 

Flooding out front of the museum during Hurricane Mathew in October, 2016

We are now planning to make the collection available as a full time museum by moving the buildings and their contents off the oceanfront to a larger site that will afford visitors the opportunity to view it on a regular basis. The new location will add a naturally landscaped     setting to what is already a unique combination of a rare National Register Historic structure,   re-purposed to house a now internationally acclaimed beachcomber's collection.

To the best of our knowledge, the last effort to move and preserve an historically significant       building in Nags Head occurred in 1988, when the circa 1932 First Colony Inn  was moved off the oceanfront to protect it from storms and preserve green space. 

The First Colony Inn as it sits today at Mile Post 16 in Nags Head: Green Space and History. 

Since that time, the historic landscapes of the northern Outer Banks have been diminished by the loss of historic structures including the Carolinian Hotel, the Baum St. Claire Coast Guard Station, and the Croatan Inn, to name a few.

Using the Inn's inspiring story as a blueprint for successful historic preservation efforts, our goal is to create a full time, privately run attraction celebrating the intersection of heritage      and habitat in the heart of the Nags Head Beach Cottage Row Historic District. With your              help, It is our plan to feature Nellie's internationally recognized collection, set in the context        of her mother’s historic grocery, as an anchor around which other important Outer Banks history can be shared with locals and visitors alike far into the future. By relocating them            to a site similar to that of their original location on the soundside, and removing them from threats inherent to its current location, they will be well suited to being shared with locals and visitors alike far into the future.

 

BACKGROUND

Chaz and I have lived on the Outer Banks for 35 years and have been involved in historic preservation since 1994, when we moved into Mattie Midgette's Store. We have produced        and promoted many educational programs and partnered with the Outer Banks History      Center in celebrating the legacy of Ras Wescott's legendary Nags Head Casino Ballroom at Festival Park in 2006. Our commitment to preserving local history is well documented and       the network of relationships we have formed during that time make us uniquely qualified              to accomplish our goal to preserve this treasured legacy.

 

Mattie Midgette's Store after Hurricane Isabel, September 19, 2003

 

Here is a slideshow of photographs Chaz took from inside the museum during Hurricane Isabel in 2013. The water came up to the door and large timbers from Jennette Pier were washing in with each set of waves that poured over the Beach Road from the turbulent oceanfront.       

Ocean over wash, storm surge, and frequent standing water on the Beach Road are a recipe for disaster for the 100 year old store and the priceless history it shelters. It is the primary reason we are "moving back and moving on" with the business of opening these irreplaceable pieces of Outer Banks History as a full time attraction.

________________________________________________________________________________________

 

Visitors at the "Touch Table" Dorothy has set up for some "Hands On" experience.

The new site will provide many opportunities for educational exhibits and outdoor areas.

______________________________________________________________

Cecelia Walton Anderson reviewed Outer Banks Beachcomber Museum — 5 star

August 31, 2017: 

"The Beachcomber Museum is even more wonderful than I expected. I wanted to go here from the first I read about it. So much to see and think about...a perfect example of "material culture" describing the people and their lifestyle."

_____________________________________

You can read more reviews HERE...

 

OUR GOAL: $235,000

This will allow us to pick up and move Mattie Midgette's Store to property we own nearby.    Julian and Stephen Bray have been working with us on this project and will be moving the buildings to the new site. After that, a foundation will be constructed of pilings and girders to accept the structures when they are lowered.

We will install parking, septic system, and a cistern for storm water management. Bathrooms, handicapped ramp, and access to the site from the road will also have to be constructed. The property will then be returned to its natural state as much as possible. All funds will be used to complete the move of the structures, prepare the site to open as a self sustaining conservation ~ preservation venture, and photograph and archive the entire collection so the inventory can be placed online at some point to assist students, scholars, and researchers, to name a few.

 

Other Ways to Help...

You can also get involved by spreading the word amongst your friends and family who                might be interested in knowing about this important preservation effort! Let us know                    if you would like to walk the property, we look forward to showing you the potential                        we see in the new site!!

Thank you for your interest, let's make some history together!!

Dorothy Hope & Chaz Winkler

252-564-5317

osobnc@gmail.com

www.osobnc.com

"Old School Outer Banks"
